G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19, 19A..proposition: The amount of damages reasonably likely to be recovered is within the jurisdictional limits of this Court. See G.L. c. 218, §§ 19, 19A.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2..proposition: Venue is proper in Lynn District Court because the events giving rise to this action occurred in Lynn, Massachusetts, and the subject premises are located at 123 Maple Street, Lynn, Massachusetts 01905. See G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 15F.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant, as landlord and property manager, owed Plaintiff, a lawful residential tenant and invitee, a duty to exercise reasonable care in the ownership, operation, inspection, repair, and maintenance of the Premises, including the common areas and common-area smoke detectors, to keep them in reasonably safe condition. See G.L. c. 186, § 15F; Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).

Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant, as landlord and property manager, owed Plaintiff, a lawful residential tenant and invitee, a duty to exercise reasonable care in the ownership, operation, inspection, repair, and maintenance of the Premises, including the common areas and common-area smoke detectors, to keep them in reasonably safe condition. See G.L. c. 186, § 15F; Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).support_reasoning: The case expressly abolishes the old common-law limitations and holds that landlords, like other persons, must exercise reasonable care not to subject others—including tenants and their guests—to unreasonable risks of harm from defective conditions on the rented premises. It also grounds this duty in both common-law negligence and cites G.L. c. 186, §§ 15 and 19 as consistent with imposing a negligence duty for unsafe conditions on or about the leased premises, regardless of whether they are common areas or part of the demised premises. Although Young does not specifically discuss smoke detectors, it clearly supports the broader proposition that a residential landlord/property manager owes tenants and their invitees a duty of reasonable care in ownership, operation, inspection, repair, and maintenance to keep the premises reasonably safe.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).relevant_excerpt: “Henceforth, landlords as other persons must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to an unreasonable risk of harm. A landlord must act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk. … Our statutes do not support limiting a landlord’s negligence liability to areas under his control. … [T]he landlord is liable in negligence for defects of which he has notice, even though the defect occurs on the rented premises.”

Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord may be held liable in negligence for failing to exercise reasonable care to prevent foreseeable harm to tenants and their guests arising from dangerous conditions in common areas. See Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980); Humphrey v. Byron, 447 Mass. 322 (2006).
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly rejects the old status-based limits on landlord liability and holds that landlords, like other persons, must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to unreasonable risk of harm. It specifically notes prior Massachusetts law imposing a duty of reasonable care as to common passageways under the landlord’s control for tenants and their guests, and extends negligence principles more broadly to rented premises. Thus, it clearly supports the proposition that, under Massachusetts law, landlords may be liable in negligence for failing to exercise reasonable care to prevent foreseeable harm to tenants and their guests from dangerous conditions in common areas (and beyond).
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).relevant_excerpt: “In the landlord-tenant field, we have held that a landlord is liable to a tenant’s guest for failing to exercise due care in maintaining common passageways under the landlord’s control without regard to their condition at the time of the letting. Lindsey v. Massios, supra. We said that ‘the status of the person visited, landowner or lessee, should not affect the visitor’s right to personal safety or the landowner’s obligation reasonably to maintain premises in his control.’ … Henceforth, landlords as other persons must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to an unreasonable risk of harm.”

Humphrey v. Byron, 447 Mass. 322 (2006).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord may be held liable in negligence for failing to exercise reasonable care to prevent foreseeable harm to tenants and their guests arising from dangerous conditions in common areas. See Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980); Humphrey v. Byron, 447 Mass. 322 (2006).
Humphrey v. Byron, 447 Mass. 322 (2006).support_reasoning: Humphrey v. Byron expressly declines to extend the Young v. Garwacki negligence duty to commercial landlords, and instead reaffirms the narrower common-law rule that a commercial landlord is liable only in limited circumstances (contract to repair performed negligently or defects in common/appurtenant areas under the landlord’s control). The proposition cited is a broad statement about landlord liability for dangerous conditions in common areas that is grounded in Young; Humphrey does not expand that duty but constrains it in the commercial context, so it should not be cited as affirmative support for the general proposition stated.
Humphrey v. Byron, 447 Mass. 322 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “In the present case, we are again asked to impose that duty on commercial landlords… We decline to impose such a duty and affirm the grant of summary judgment… Our decision today leaves intact the rule that ‘a lessor of commercial premises is liable in tort for personal injuries only if either (1) he contracted to make repairs and made them negligently, or (2) the defect that caused the injury was in a “common area,” or other area appurtenant to the leased area, over which the lessor had some control.’”

G.L. c. 148, \u00a7\u00a7 26F, 26F\u00bd.proposition: The Massachusetts State Sanitary Code and applicable fire safety regulations require that residential landlords provide and maintain operational smoke detectors and fire warning systems in common areas for the protection of occupants. See, e.g., G.L. c. 148, §§ 26F, 26F½; 780 CMR (Massachusetts State Building Code) and 527 CMR (Massachusetts Comprehensive Fire Safety Code) as applicable.

780 CMR (Massachusetts State Building Co.proposition: The Massachusetts State Sanitary Code and applicable fire safety regulations require that residential landlords provide and maintain operational smoke detectors and fire warning systems in common areas for the protection of occupants. See, e.g., G.L. c. 148, §§ 26F, 26F½; 780 CMR (Massachusetts State Building Code) and 527 CMR (Massachusetts Comprehensive Fire Safety Code) as applicable.

527 CMR (Massachusetts Comprehensive Fir.proposition: The Massachusetts State Sanitary Code and applicable fire safety regulations require that residential landlords provide and maintain operational smoke detectors and fire warning systems in common areas for the protection of occupants. See, e.g., G.L. c. 148, §§ 26F, 26F½; 780 CMR (Massachusetts State Building Code) and 527 CMR (Massachusetts Comprehensive Fire Safety Code) as applicable.

Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.raw_text: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355 (1990)
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.proposition: Failure to comply with such statutory and regulatory requirements, where intended to protect tenants from fire-related harm, constitutes evidence of negligence. See Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355 (1990); Perry v. Medeiros, 369 Mass. 836 (1976).
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.support_reasoning: The case does discuss statutory violations as evidence of negligence, but it is about a liquor-liability statute (G.L. c. 138, § 69), not statutory or regulatory requirements intended to protect tenants from fire-related harm. The opinion reiterates the general Massachusetts rule that violation of such a statute is only "some evidence" of negligence, but it does not concern tenants, fire safety, or premises-fire regulations. Thus, it does not specifically support the tenant/fire-related proposition for which it is cited, though it is consistent with the broader negligence-evidence principle.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.relevant_excerpt: “It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se. … Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only ‘some evidence’ of the defendant’s negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., supra. Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 499 (1968).”

Perry v. Medeiros, 369 Mass. 836 (1976).proposition: Failure to comply with such statutory and regulatory requirements, where intended to protect tenants from fire-related harm, constitutes evidence of negligence. See Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355 (1990); Perry v. Medeiros, 369 Mass. 836 (1976).
Perry v. Medeiros, 369 Mass. 836 (1976).support_reasoning: The opinion directly applies the general Massachusetts rule that violation of a safety statute, ordinance, or regulation is not itself a cause of action but is evidence of negligence as to the harms the rule was intended to prevent. The court holds that the excluded building code provision—aimed at preventing falls on stairs—should have been admitted so the jury could consider the code violation as evidence of the landlord’s negligence, fitting the proposition that failure to comply with such safety requirements is evidence of negligence.
Perry v. Medeiros, 369 Mass. 836 (1976).relevant_excerpt: “With the benefit of the excluded portion of § 6.08 the jury could have found that there was a violation of the building code which contributed to the plaintiff’s injury. ‘The general rule in Massachusetts is that violation of the safety statute or ordinance does not in itself give rise to a cause of action but is evidence of negligence.’ … [V]iolation of a safety statute, ordinance or regulation … ‘is evidence of negligence on the part of a violator as to all consequences that the statute, ordinance or regulation was intended to prevent.’”

Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79 (1977).proposition: At a minimum, Defendant had constructive notice of the defective condition because a reasonably careful landlord, exercising ordinary inspection and maintenance of common areas, would have discovered and remedied a nonfunctioning smoke detector with a battery visibly removed and left on a windowsill. See Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79 (1977); Fiorentino v. Mason, 233 Mass. 451 (1919).
Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79 (1977).support_reasoning: Lindsey concerns a missing light bulb in a tenement hallway and holds that a landlord owes lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care, and that violation of the hallway-lighting statute is evidence of negligence. The opinion does not discuss smoke detectors, batteries, or the specific concept that a landlord, through ordinary inspection, would have constructive notice of a visibly disabled safety device. While it supports the broader principle of a duty of reasonable care in maintaining common areas and that statutory safety violations are evidence of negligence, it does not specifically support the constructive-notice proposition about a nonfunctioning smoke detector with a battery left on a windowsill.
Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79 (1977).relevant_excerpt: "The amount of light cast on the stairway in question is relevant to the issue of negligence because this factor assists the jury in deciding whether Massios took reasonable measures to ensure the safe passage of visitors on her stairway after dark. Evidence of the absence of the light bulb in the second floor landing’s light fixture, and evidence from which it could be inferred that the bulb was missing for ten days, was therefore admissible."

Fiorentino v. Mason, 233 Mass. 451 (1919.proposition: At a minimum, Defendant had constructive notice of the defective condition because a reasonably careful landlord, exercising ordinary inspection and maintenance of common areas, would have discovered and remedied a nonfunctioning smoke detector with a battery visibly removed and left on a windowsill. See Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79 (1977); Fiorentino v. Mason, 233 Mass. 451 (1919).
Fiorentino v. Mason, 233 Mass. 451 (1919.support_reasoning: Fiorentino v. Mason does not address constructive notice or a landlord’s duty arising from ordinary inspection of common areas. Instead, it discusses when an express contractual undertaking by a landlord creates an affirmative duty to inspect and keep demised premises safe, and concludes that such an onerous duty was not established on the facts. The case therefore does not support the proposition that, even absent such a special contract, a landlord has constructive notice of a defect that reasonable inspection would have revealed (such as a nonfunctioning smoke detector with a removed battery).
Fiorentino v. Mason, 233 Mass. 451 (1919.relevant_excerpt: “It can be supported and proved only by evidence far more explicit than a mere general agreement to maintain in repair. It imposes an obligation on the landlord to enter upon the demised premises at all reasonable times for the purpose of inspection and ascertainment of any defective condition. The landlord thereby assumes direct and initial responsibility for the condition of the premises as to safety at all times. Under such an agreement liability devolves upon the landlord for any failure reasonably to discover and remedy a defect or want of repair whereby injury ensues…”

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 58 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s negligence need not be the sole cause of Plaintiff’s injuries; it is sufficient that Defendant’s negligence was a substantial contributing factor in producing Plaintiff’s harm. See Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 58 (1983); Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 254 (1935).
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: The quoted portion is a dissent focused on whether the plaintiff proved proximate cause on the facts; it does not discuss or articulate the legal standard that negligence need not be the sole cause so long as it is a substantial contributing factor. There is no language adopting or applying a “substantial contributing factor” causation standard. Thus, this text from Mullins does not provide authority for the proposition cited, even if the majority opinion elsewhere might.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: In my opinion the plaintiff failed to introduce sufficient evidence to warrant a finding that action or inaction of the defendants was the proximate cause of her injury, and the defendants were entitled to directed verdicts and judgments in their favor.

Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 254 (1.proposition: Defendant’s negligence need not be the sole cause of Plaintiff’s injuries; it is sufficient that Defendant’s negligence was a substantial contributing factor in producing Plaintiff’s harm. See Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 58 (1983); Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 254 (1935).
Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 254 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly adopts a proximate cause standard under which the defendant remains liable so long as his negligence continues as an “operative and potent factor,” even when other instrumentalities (such as disease germs) cooperate to produce the final injury. It further states that where an injury combines with a preexisting or subsequently acquired disease to cause greater harm, the defendant is liable for all consequences. This aligns with the idea that the defendant’s negligence need not be the sole cause, only a substantial contributing factor to the harm.
Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 254 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The proximate cause is that which in a continuous sequence, unbroken by any new cause, produces an event and without which the event would not have occurred. It may be assisted or accelerated by other incidental and ancillary matters, but, if it continues as an operative and potent factor, the chain of causation is not broken. … It is settled that, where an injury arising from a cause which entails liability on the defendant combines with a preexisting or a subsequently acquired disease to bring about greater harm to the plaintiff than would have resulted from the injury alone, the defendant may be liable for all the consequences.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: To the extent Defendant contends that the negligence of any other person or entity contributed to Plaintiff’s injuries, Defendant remains liable under Massachusetts comparative negligence principles for its proportionate share of fault and responsibility. See G.L. c. 231, § 85; Zeller v. Cantu, 395 Mass. 76 (1985).

Zeller v. Cantu, 395 Mass. 76 (1985).proposition: To the extent Defendant contends that the negligence of any other person or entity contributed to Plaintiff’s injuries, Defendant remains liable under Massachusetts comparative negligence principles for its proportionate share of fault and responsibility. See G.L. c. 231, § 85; Zeller v. Cantu, 395 Mass. 76 (1985).

doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776 (.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover full and fair compensation for all injuries and damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including but not limited to medical expenses, lost wages, damage to personal property, pain and suffering, emotional distress, and all other permissible damages under Massachusetts law. See, e.g., doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776 (1975); Jones v. Wayland, 374 Mass. 249 (1978).
doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776 (.support_reasoning: The opinion does not set out a general black-letter rule about the full catalogue of compensable tort damages under Massachusetts law, but it does implicitly recognize that a plaintiff in a negligence/products case is entitled to broad compensatory damages, including pain and suffering, loss of earning capacity, and other noneconomic harms. In reviewing the alleged excessiveness of the verdict, the court expressly lists and accepts a wide range of injury-related elements the jury could consider, which aligns with the notion of ‘full and fair’ compensation for all proximately caused injuries and damages. However, it does not separately analyze items like medical expenses or property damage, so its support is indirect rather than an explicit doctrinal statement.
doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776 (.relevant_excerpt: “In concluding that the judge committed no error of law, we consider Ezila’s age (twenty-nine) and weekly earnings ($140) at the time of the accident; the loss of ninety-five per cent of the function of her right hand (her dominant hand); her inability to perform many household tasks or to obtain employment; her pain and suffering… her disfigurement… her future need for artificial hands; and her continuing discomfort and embarrassment… We find no abuse of discretion.”

Jones v. Wayland, 374 Mass. 249 (1978).proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover full and fair compensation for all injuries and damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including but not limited to medical expenses, lost wages, damage to personal property, pain and suffering, emotional distress, and all other permissible damages under Massachusetts law. See, e.g., doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776 (1975); Jones v. Wayland, 374 Mass. 249 (1978).
Jones v. Wayland, 374 Mass. 249 (1978).support_reasoning: The case is not a tort damages case and does not discuss the scope of compensable personal injury damages such as medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, or emotional distress. Instead, it interprets G.L. c. 41, § 111F regarding paid leave for incapacitated police officers, issues about resignation, and offsets for insurance, in a statutory employment-benefits context. It therefore does not provide authority for the broad proposition about ‘full and fair compensation’ for all tort damages under Massachusetts negligence law.
Jones v. Wayland, 374 Mass. 249 (1978).relevant_excerpt: “Wayland, however, is not obligated under § 111F to compensate Jones for loss of sight or medical expenses. Thus, the issue concerning the computation of damages is whether the portion, if any, of the policy payment allocable to indemnity may be deducted from the amount which Wayland must pay to Jones as compensation under § 111F.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 60 and applicable rules, Plaintiff demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pre-judgment and post-judgment interest as allowed by law, including pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

G.L. c. 261, \u00a7 1 et seq..proposition: Costs of this action, including allowable filing fees and other taxable costs, pursuant to G.L. c. 261, § 1 et seq.;
